author: Captain Greybeard
title: Global demand for cruise holidays hits record levels but UK passenger numbers fall
text:
Global demand for cruise holidays has passed 22million passengers for the first time, with an increase of almost 70% in the last decade, new figures reveal.
But while numbers rise in most parts of the world, with North America accounting for 12.2million of the total, the UK seems to be falling out of love with the sea and ships.
Germany has overtaken us as Europe’s biggest source market, and the number of British passengers fell by almost 5% in 2014, according to the Cruise Lines International Association (CLIA).
But at 1.61million passengers, that still leaves us as the third biggest market in the world – ahead of a rapidly-growing Australia (one million) and double the number of Italians.
“The potential for new cruise passenger growth is huge,” said CLIA’s Cindy D’Aoust. “Apart from North America and Europe, other regions account for nearly 85% of the world’s population, yet represent only 16% of cruisers.
“That reflects a big opportunity for the cruise industry.”
CLIA’s 2014 Asia Cruise Trends Study shows the number of cruise ships in Asia between 2013 and 2015 grew by 10% a year, with passenger capacity increasing by 20%.
“Asia is a prime example of the cruise industry’s growth opportunity,” said D’Aoust. “Our industry is bringing more cruise ship visits to Asia.”
The latest development came in London this week, when Chinese President Xi Jinping and David Cameron were present as Carnival Corporation signed a $4billion deal to set up a joint venture operating a fleet of ships devoted to China.
